prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UGC 7321
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal describes the observational setup requested to obtain a Band 7 dust continuum pointing near the center of the edge-on galaxy UGC 7321. We will use these data to measure the dust scale height. As a secondary goal, we request CO(3-2) observations in one of the basebands.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The continuum observations are our main goal. We chose the correlator setup to be similar to the standard continuum-only setup while also allowing for CO(3-2) observations in one baseband. We selected TDM mode for the three continuum basebands and the lowest-resolution FDM mode with 0.98 MHz (~1 km/s) resolution for the baseband where we expect CO(3-2). This spectral resolution gives good sampling of the CO(3-2) line width, which we expect to be up to 50 km/s.

The angular resolution of 1.15'' will allow us to resolve the vertical distribution of dust (FWHM~5'') with 4.3 resolution elements. We also expect the vertical distribution of dust to be within 1/3 of the primary beam. We expect emission along the major axis to fill the primary beam, so we can measure the scale height at multiple positions as a function of radius.
Holwerda et al. (2012) modeled the surface brightness distribution of the edge-on galaxy NGC 4244 and concluded that a purely clumpy distribution of dust provided a better match to the observed spectral energy distribution than a smooth dust distribution. The model included clumps with a diameter ~ 200 pc, which is 4.1'' at the distance of UGC 7321. We expect this to be our largest angular structure. We should recover emission on this scale since it is smaller than the maximum recoverable scale for our chosen ALMA configuration (9.3'').

Our main goal is to resolve the vertical distribution of the dust continuum near 850 microns in the edge-on galaxy UGC 7321. We used the Herschel 500 micron map from the NHEMESES survey (Holwerda et al. 2011) to measure the 500 micron flux density per Herschel beam at our selected position for the ALMA observations. We estimated the flux density per Herschel beam near 850 microns using this 500 micron value and assuming a single-temperature blackbody curve with T=25 K, modified by an emissivity law proportional to wavelength to the -1.5 power (Skibba et al. 2011). We then estimated the 850 micron flux density per ALMA beam by dividing by the number of ALMA beams over which the flux density would be distributed. For UGC 7321, the number of ALMA beams is the Herschel beam size (~35'') times the expected FWHM of the vertical dust distribution (~5'') and divided by the ALMA beam area.
This calculation gives the average surface brightness we expect in our ALMA observations. With an rms of 31.04 microJy per beam, we expect to detect the average surface brightness with a SNR=8. We also aim to significantly detect emission at one scale height above and below the mid-plane, where the surface brightness may be up to a factor of e lower than the average value. With an rms of 31.04 microJy per beam, we will detect with at least SNR=3 the emission at one scale height above and below the mid-plane.
We estimated the CO(3-2) surface brightness for UGC 7321 from the 250 micron flux density per Herschel beam at our selected position for the ALMA observations. We used the relationship between the 250 micron flux density and the CO(1-0) flux for spiral galaxies (Corbelli et al. 2012). We assumed a CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) ratio of 0.31 (Wilson et al. 2009). We then carried out the correction for the number of ALMA beams over which the CO(3-2) emission will be distributed.
In the 48 minutes on-source that are required for our dust continuum observations, we expect to obtain SNR=2 on the average CO(3-2) surface brightness (after integrating over velocity). The CO(3-2) observations are worthwhile because the ISM is clumpy, so we may significantly detect regions with above-average surface brightness. We also plan to stack along the major axis to derive the CO scale height in this galaxy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: There is a transition in the appearance of dust in optical images of edge-on, bulgeless disk galaxies at a circular velocity of 120 km/s (stellar mass ~ 10^10 M_sun). This transition is most likely due to a transition in the dust scale height, but could also be explained by a transition in the dust-to-gas ratio or in the backlighting by the stellar disk. We propose observations of four edge-on, bulgeless disk galaxies that will spatially resolve the vertical distribution of the dust continuum near 850 microns. With these data, we will answer the following questions: Is there a dust scale height transition at 120 km/s? And does turbulence driven by star formation cause the transition in the structure of the interstellar medium? We request a total of 4.3 hours, which includes a single 850 micron continuum pointing near the center of each galaxy and simultaneous CO(3-2) observations.
